item.title: AWS Parameter Store
item.description: Abstract Â§ A central place to store the parameters used by others AWS Services Update Programmatically Â§ One common use case of this service is to add/delete/access/modify the parameters Doing these operations programmatically is less error prone & faster 1) Install aws-parameter-bulk Â§ brew tap gork74/gork7 brew install aws-parameter-bulk 2) Carry out the operation Â§ # Grab all the parameters from <YOUR_AWS_PROFILE> from the <YOUR_AWS_REGION>, and save them to your current directory in a file called `.

item.title: MacOs Setup
item.description: Note ğŸŒŸ denotes tools & settings I must have in MacOS to have a smooth user/developer experience GUI Apps Â§ Install Firefox (Replaced with floorp) ğŸŒŸ Install Bypass Paywalls Install Dropbox Install Obsidian ğŸŒŸ Install Keypass (Replaced with Install StrongBox from App Store) ğŸŒŸ Install VSC ğŸŒŸ Add code into cli Install Termius ğŸŒŸ Modify Default Shell Install Tutanota ğŸŒŸ Install Notion ğŸŒŸ Install Docker (Replaced with OrbStack) ğŸŒŸ Install Podman Install Node Version Manager, npm included ğŸŒŸ Install Postman Install GitKraken ğŸŒŸ Install Brave Install MySQL Workbench Install Google Drive Client ğŸŒŸ Install Java JDK ğŸŒŸ Install IntelliJ Community ğŸŒŸ Install VirtualBox Install Ngrok # Move Ngrok Executable to PATH cp ngrok /Users/<USERNAME>/.

item.title: IEEE 754 Floating-Point Rep (æµ®ç‚¹æ•°ç¼–ç )
item.description: Abstract Â§ sign 0 for positive, 1 for negative exponent by default -127 with all bits set to 0 mantissa takes the binary behind the decimal place after normalisation (the yellow circle part) Reliable precision is 7 decimal digits Approximation of Real Number Â§ mantissa gives the precision From 1 to 2 (2^0-2^1), there are 23 bits of mantissa used for precision after decision point For 2 to 4 (2^1-2^2), there are 22 bits of mantissa used for precision after decision point, one of the bit is used to present the whole number before decimal point With every range of 2, the precision after the decimal point is reduced by 2 Thus, the precision of the number after decimal point is getting worse as the number getting bigger Normalised Number Â§ The range of real numbers between 0 and smallest Normalised Number isnâ€™t covered, covered by Subnormal Number (Denormalized Number) The 1 is implicit when exponent isnâ€™t 0.

item.title: Sign-and-Magnitude (åŸç )
item.description: Abstract Â§ Represent positive and negative decimal integers in binary Divide the number of bits into 2 parts, one part for negative number, another part for positive number Cons Â§ Require extra Logic Gates Â§ The Adder logic cant be used for subtraction This can be avoided using 1â€™s Complement (åç ) or 2â€™s Complement (è¡¥ç ) Terminologies Â§ Sign Bit Â§ The first bit from left 0 denotes positive 1 denotes negative Reference Â§ Hello-Algo .

item.title: 1's Complement (åç )
item.description: Abstract Â§ For negative number, all bits are inverted except the Sign Bit which is 1 when we need to perform the computation Benefits Â§ Reuse Logic Gates Â§ We re-can use Adder logic gates, without building extra logic circuit like a subtraction logic gates Cons Â§ Mathematically wrong definition of 0 Â§ We have +0 (when all bits are 0) & -0(when all bits are 1) under this encoding, this can be solved by 2â€™s Complement (è¡¥ç ) .

item.title: 2's Complement (è¡¥ç )
item.description: Abstract Â§ We are adding extra 1 to the 1â€™s Complement (åç ) This makes sure that there is only one 0 by adding 1 to after converting from Sign-and-Magnitude (åŸç ) to 1â€™s Complement (åç ) .

item.title: Immediate Value (16 bits, 2's Complement)
item.description: #computer_organisation Abstract Used for PC-Relative Addressing 16-bits, can represent up to +-2^15 Word, 2^17 Memory Address because 4-bytes Word Addressing Warning 2's Complement (è¡¥ç ) .

item.title: Rule of Inference (æ¨ç†è§„åˆ™)
item.description: Abstract Â§ Logical rule that allows us to derive a Conclusion from a set of Premise A form of Mathematical Argument that is Valid Examples rules are Modus Ponens, Modus Tollens Tools that enable Deductive Reasoning (æ¼”ç¹¹æ¨ç†) Basics Â§ Modus Ponens Â§ Modus Tollens Â§ Denying the consequent Generalization Â§ Case 1 Â§ Premise: p Conclusion: p v q Case 2 Â§ Premise: q Conclusion: p v q Specilisation Â§ Allow us to discard some information to focus on things that we are interested Case 1 Â§ Premise: p AND q Conclusion: p Case 2 Â§ Premise: p AND q Conclusion: q Elimination Â§ Case 1 Â§ Premise: p v q, ~q Conclusion: p Case 2 Â§ Premise: p v q, ~p Conclusion: q Transitivity Â§ Premise: p -> q, q -> r Conclusion: p -> r Division into Cases Â§ Premise: p v q, p -> r, q -> r Conclusion: r The above only 2 cases, we can have more than 2 cases Contradiction Rule Â§ Premise: ~p -> false Conclusion: p The core of Proof by Contradiction (åè¯æ³•) If a assumption leads to a contradiction, then that assumption must be false With Quantifiers Â§ Universal Modus Ponens Â§ Premise: For all x, if x makes P(x) true, then x makes Q(x) true Premise: a is an element of x, a makes P(x) true Conclusion: a makes Q(x) true .

item.title: Read-After-Write(RAW) Hazard
item.description: Abstract Â§ x is only ready at t=5 since thereâ€™s where the first Instruction finishes Can be countered with simple Pipeline Stall or more complex Operand Forwarding .

item.description: Abstract Â§ Note å‘æ—¥è‘µæœç€å¤ªé˜³è½¬åŠ¨ï¼Œ æ—¶åˆ»éƒ½åœ¨å¯»æ±‚å½“å‰æ±²å–æœ€å¤§å…»åˆ†çš„å¯èƒ½ã€‚ æœ€ä¼˜å­ç»“æ„å°±æ˜¯è¿½éšå¤ªé˜³æœ€é«˜æ•ˆçš„ç§»åŠ¨è½¨è¿¹ã€‚ ç§»é™¤é‡å¤å­é—®é¢˜è®©å‘æ—¥è‘µç´§è·Ÿå¤ªé˜³çš„è„šæ­¥ã€‚ è´ªå¿ƒç­–ç•¥åœ¨ä¸€è½®è½®çš„ç®€å•é€‰æ‹©ä¸­ï¼Œé€æ­¥å¯¼å‘æœ€ä½³çš„ç­”æ¡ˆã€‚ Used to solve Optimisation Problem Usually better performance than Backtracking & Dynamic Programming Think about what is the Local Optimal Solution.
